definition.text: to become unconscious

examples.text: For a few seconds, he thought he was going to black out.

definition.text: to put a dark mark over something so that it cannot be seen

examples.text: The censors had blacked out several words.

definition.text: to hide or turn off all the lights in a town or city, especially during war

meaning.translation: خاموشی تمام چراغ های یک شهر

definition.text: if a fire burns out or burns itself out, it stops burning because there is no coal, wood etc left

examples.text: He left the fire to burn itself out .

definition.text: if a building or vehicle is burnt out, the inside of it is destroyed by fire

examples.text: The hotel was completely burnt out. Only the walls remained.
We passed several burnt out cars.

definition.text: to remove something by burning it

examples.text: The cancer cells are burnt out using a laser beam.

definition.text: to work so hard over a period of time that you become unable to continue working because you are tired, ill, or unable to think of any new ideas

examples.text: It’s a high-pressure job and you could burn out young.
be/get burnt out
He was almost burnt out by the time he was 21.
burn yourself out
She’s in danger of burning herself out.

definition.text: if an engine or electric wire burns out or is burnt out, it stops working because it has been damaged by getting too hot

examples.text: The plugs are wired so that if one burns out, the others will still start the engine.
burn something ↔ out
I think you’ve burnt out one of the gaskets.

definition.text: if a rocket or jet burns out, it stops working because all its fuel has been used
the body of a dead animal
the decaying outer structure of a building, vehicle, or other object
a special quality someone or something has that makes people like them, feel attracted to them, or be easily influenced by them – used to show approval

examples.text: Joe’s boyish charm
charm of
the charm of this small Southern city
She turned on the charm (= used her charm ) to all the men.
The room had no windows and all the charm of a prison cell (= used to say that something has no charm ) .

definition.text: a very small object worn on a chain or bracelet

examples.text: a charm bracelet
a small gold horseshoe worn as a lucky charm

definition.text: a phrase or action believed to have special magic powers
to work exactly as you had hoped

examples.text: The new sales program has worked like a charm.

definition.text: to attract someone and make them like you, sometimes in order to make them do something for you

examples.text: We were charmed by the friendliness of the local people.

definition.text: to please and interest someone

meaning.translation: رضایتمند کردن و علاقه مند کردن

examples.text: a story that has charmed generations of children

definition.text: to gain power over someone or something by using magic
to be unable to breathe properly because something is in your throat or there is not enough air

examples.text: choke on
He choked on a piece of bread.
Six people choked to death on the fumes.

definition.text: if something chokes you, it makes you unable to breathe properly

examples.text: I felt as if there was a weight on my chest, choking me.
The smoke was choking me.

definition.text: to prevent someone from breathing by putting your hands around their throat and pressing on it

examples.text: His hands were round her throat, choking her.

definition.text: to be unable to talk clearly because you are feeling a strong emotion

examples.text: choke with
He was choking with rage.
I was too choked with emotion to speak.
Her voice was choked with rage.

definition.text: to say something with difficulty because you are very upset or angry

examples.text: ‘Get out, ’ she choked.

definition.text: to fill a place so that things cannot move through it

examples.text: Weeds were choking the stream.
be choked (up) with something
The gutters were choked up with leaves.

definition.text: to fail at doing something, especially a sport, because there is a lot of pressure on you

examples.text: People said I choked, but I just had a bad day on the golf course.

definition.text: if one plant chokes another, it kills it by growing all around it and taking away its light and room to grow

examples.text: Weeds can quickly choke delicate garden plants.

definition.text: if you say that something is big enough to choke a horse, you are emphasizing that it is very big

examples.text: a wad of bills big enough to choke a horse

definition.text: a piece of equipment in a vehicle that controls the amount of air going into the engine, and that is used to help the engine start
the sound that someone makes when they cannot breathe properly because something is in their throat or there is not enough air

meaning.translation: صدایی که یک شخص در حال خفگی ایجاد میکنه

examples.text: She gave a little choke of laughter.

definition.text: a place on a farm where milk is kept and butter and cheese are made
a company which sells milk and sometimes makes other things from milk, such as cheese
milk, butter, cheese etc
a definitive book, description etc is considered to be the best and cannot be improved

examples.text: definitive study/work/guide etc
the definitive study of Victorian railway stations

definition.text: a definitive agreement, statement etc is one that will not be changed

examples.text: a definitive agreement to buy the company

definition.text: an area of land where golf is played
your gums are the two areas of firm pink flesh at the top and bottom of your mouth, in which your teeth are fixed
chewing gum
a type of glue used to stick light things such as paper together
a sticky substance found in the stems of some trees
a gum tree

meaning.translation: درخت صمغ (هر نوع درختی که صمغ می دهد مثل اوکالیپتوس و غیره)

definition.text: used to express surprise
to stick things together using glue

examples.text: gum something to something
A large label had been gummed to the back of the photograph.

definition.text: someone who is eligible for something is able or allowed to do it, for example because they are the right age

examples.text: eligible for
Students on a part-time course are not eligible for a loan.
eligible to do something
Over 500,000 18-year-olds will become eligible to vote this year.

definition.text: an eligible man or woman would be good to marry because they are rich, attractive, and not married

examples.text: Stephen was regarded as an eligible bachelor .

definition.text: an eight-day Jewish holiday in November or December
to support something and prevent it from falling down

examples.text: The roof is held up by massive stone pillars.

definition.text: to delay someone or something

examples.text: Sorry I’m late – I was held up at work.

definition.text: to rob or try to rob a place or person by using violence

examples.text: Two armed men held up a downtown liquor store last night.

definition.text: to not become weaker

examples.text: His physical condition has held up well.

definition.text: a situation that stops something from happening or making progress

examples.text: traffic hold-ups on the highway
Despite the odd hold-up, we finished on time.

definition.text: an attempt to rob a place or person by threatening them with a weapon

examples.text: a bank hold-up

definition.text: a child who behaves badly, but in a way that is funny
a small creature in stories who has magic powers and behaves very badly
showing a lack of respect or seriousness in a way that is amusing rather than bad

examples.text: a little girl with dark hair and an impish grin

definition.text: the money that people have collected for a particular purpose

examples.text: How much money is there left in the kitty?

definition.text: the money that the winner of a game of cards receives
a word for a cat, used especially by children
to provide the conditions that will make it possible for something to happen or be successful

examples.text: lay the foundations/groundwork/base for
Mandela helped lay the foundations for a new democratic South Africa.
It was an invention which laid the foundations of modern radio technology.

definition.text: to hate someone or something very much

examples.text: He loathes their politics.
loathe doing something
I absolutely loathe shopping.

definition.text: to steal things, especially from shops or homes that have been damaged in a war or riot

meaning.translation: دزدی کردن بویژه از مغازه ها و خانه هایی که در یک جنگ یا شورش آسیب دیده اند

examples.text: Shops were looted and burned.

definition.text: goods taken by soldiers from a place where they have won a battle
goods or money that have been stolen

meaning.translation: کالا ها یا پول دزدیده شده

definition.text: things that you have bought or been given in large amounts – used humorously

examples.text: Jodie came home from the mall with bags of loot.

definition.text: a magazine, sold in the UK and the US, which only contains advertisements . It is typically used by people who want to sell their cars or old furniture, rent their homes, buy a house etc. It also appears on the Internet .
to make a special effort to remember something

examples.text: Sarah made a mental note to ask Janine about it later.

definition.text: to damage or injure something badly by crushing or twisting it

meaning.translation: آسیب زدن به چیزی با کوبیدن یا پیچوندنش

examples.text: The trap closed round her leg, badly mangling her ankle.

definition.text: to spoil something such as a speech or piece of music, by saying or playing it badly

meaning.translation: خراب کردن یک سخنرانی یااجرای موسیقی

examples.text: The orchestra had mangled Bach’s music.

definition.text: a machine used in former times to remove water from washed clothes by pressing them between two rollers
the person who has been elected to lead the government of a town or city

examples.text: the election of the London mayor

definition.text: someone who is chosen or elected each year in Britain to represent a town or city at official public ceremonies
a type of golf game, played for fun, in which you hit a small ball through passages, over bridges and small hills etc
used to show that one number or quantity is being subtracted from another

examples.text: The payment will be refunded to you minus a small service charge.

definition.text: without something that would normally be there, or that used to be there

examples.text: He came back minus a couple of front teeth.

definition.text: something that is a disadvantage because it makes a situation unpleasant

examples.text: There are both pluses and minuses to living in a big city.

definition.text: a minus sign
used to talk about a disadvantage of a thing or situation

examples.text: ‘Any minus points?’ ‘Well, the engine is rather noisy.’
On the minus side, there is no free back-up service if things go wrong.

definition.text: less than zero – used especially when talking about temperatures

examples.text: At night temperatures sometimes fall to minus 30°.
a minus quantity

definition.text: a mark used in a system of judging students’ work. An ‘A minus ’ is slightly lower than an ‘A’, but higher than a ‘ B ’.
a small two-wheeled vehicle with an engine
to start living in a new home

meaning.translation: شروع کردن به زندگی در یک خانه جدید

examples.text: When are you moving in?
Mom and Dad had always planned to move into a smaller house when we grew up.

definition.text: to start living with someone in the same home

meaning.translation: شروع کردن به زندگی با یک نفر در یک خانه

examples.text: with
Steve’s going to move in with her.

definition.text: to start being involved in and controlling a situation that someone else controlled previously

examples.text: The big multinationals moved in and started pushing up prices.
on
Investors moved in on a group of car enthusiasts and took over the market.

definition.text: to go towards a place or group of people, in order to attack them or take control of them

examples.text: on
Police moved in on the demonstrators in the square.

definition.text: to perform official duties, especially at a religious ceremony
not as good or important as some people think or say

meaning.translation: بیش از حد بها داده شده ، الکی گنده شده

examples.text: a vastly overrated film

definition.text: a large bird, the male of which has long blue and green tail feathers that it can lift up and spread out
a hole or container that has been specially made and filled with water so that people can swim or play in it

examples.text: SYN swimming pool
They have a nice pool in their backyard.

definition.text: a small area of still water in a hollow place

examples.text: pools of water with tiny fish in them
Mosquitoes breed in stagnant pools of water.

definition.text: a small area of liquid or light on a surface

meaning.translation: یک ناحیه کوچک از آب/خون/نور و غیره روی یک سطح

examples.text: A guard found him lying in a pool of blood.
a pool of light formed by the street lamp above

definition.text: a game in which you use a stick to hit numbered balls into holes around a table, which is often played in bars

examples.text: shoot/play pool
We went to the pub and played pool.

definition.text: a group of people who are available to work or to do an activity when they are needed

examples.text: pool of
a pool of talented applicants to choose from
The region has a large and talented labour pool .

definition.text: a number of things that are shared or an amount of money that is shared by a group of people

examples.text: Both partners put money into a common pool.

definition.text: a system in Britain in which people try to win money each week by guessing the results of football games

examples.text: I do the pools sometimes.
Dad won £40 on the pools .

definition.text: a game in which people try to win money by guessing the result of a sports game, or the money that is collected from these people for this

examples.text: the office basketball pool

definition.text: to combine your money, ideas, skills etc with those of other people so that you can all use them

examples.text: Investors agreed to pool their resources to develop the property.
The students worked together, pooling their knowledge.

definition.text: someone who is specially trained to perform religious duties and ceremonies in the Christian church
a man with religious duties and responsibilities in some non-Christian religions
if someone is in the priesthood, they are a Christian priest

examples.text: He is celebrating 30 years in the priesthood.
There has been a decline in the number of people joining the priesthood.

definition.text: all the priests of a particular religion or country

examples.text: an attempt to reduce the influence of the priesthood in the country

definition.text: a Jewish priest
a journey in a vehicle, when you are not driving

examples.text: ride in
He invited me to go for a ride in his new car.
Can you give me a ride back to town?
Sammy had promised to take me for a ride in his truck.
I managed to get a ride down to the station.
We hitched a ride (= got a free ride from a passing vehicle ) into town.
car/bus/train etc ride
A fifteen minute taxi ride will take you to the airport.
a smooth/comfortable/bumpy etc ride
The new model offers a lovely smooth, comfortable ride.

definition.text: a journey on a bicycle, a horse, or a similar animal

examples.text: ride on
Can I have a ride on your bike?
a bike/bicycle ride
Shall we go for a bike ride this afternoon?

definition.text: if people give someone, especially someone in authority, a rough or an easy ride, they make a situation difficult or easy for them

examples.text: Journalists gave the prime minister a rough ride at the press conference.
The chairman will face a rough ride from shareholders.
The president will not have an easy ride when he gives his account of events.

definition.text: if something has a bumpy ride, it experiences a lot of problems

examples.text: Shares had a bumpy ride yesterday, falling by an average of 15%.
The new bill could be in for a bumpy ride when it is put before parliament.

definition.text: to trick someone, especially in order to get money from them

examples.text: I’d just begun to realise he was taking me for a ride.

definition.text: to join what other people are doing just for pleasure, not because you are seriously interested in it

examples.text: A couple of friends had come along for the ride.

definition.text: a large machine that people ride on for fun at a fair

examples.text: We went on loads of rides .

definition.text: a path for riding on a horse in the countryside

examples.text: a grassy ride

inflections: ( past tense rode / rəʊd $ roʊd /, past participle ridden / ˈrɪdn / )
title: ride_verb_1

definition.text: to sit on an animal, especially a horse, and make it move along

examples.text: She learned to ride when she was seven.
He was riding a large grey mare.
ride on
She arrived riding on a white horse.
ride away/across/through etc
He rode away across the marshes.

inflections: ( past tense rode / rəʊd $ roʊd /, past participle ridden / ˈrɪdn / )
title: ride_verb_2

definition.text: to travel on a bicycle or motorbike

meaning.translation: با دوچرخه یا موتورسیکلت جا به جا شدن

examples.text: He had never learned to ride a bicycle.
They mounted their bikes and rode off.

inflections: ( past tense rode / rəʊd $ roʊd /, past participle ridden / ˈrɪdn / )
title: ride_verb_3

definition.text: to travel in a bus, car, or other vehicle that you are not driving

meaning.translation: جا به جا شدن با یک وسیله نقلیه وقتی که خودت رانندگی نکنی

examples.text: We got onto the bus and rode into San Francisco.
ride in
The kids were riding in the back.
ride a bus
Ann rides the bus to work.

inflections: ( past tense rode / rəʊd $ roʊd /, past participle ridden / ˈrɪdn / )
title: ride_verb_4

definition.text: to travel up or down in a lift

examples.text: ride up/down
He rode the elevator down to the first floor.
I rode up to the tenth floor.

inflections: ( past tense rode / rəʊd $ roʊd /, past participle ridden / ˈrɪdn / )
title: ride_verb_5

definition.text:
a) to be floating in water or in the air
b) to float on a wave and move forward with it

examples.text: The smaller boat was lighter and rode higher in the water.
The moon was riding high in the sky.
There was a large ship riding at anchor in the bay.
surfboarders riding the waves

inflections: ( past tense rode / rəʊd $ roʊd /, past participle ridden / ˈrɪdn / )
title: ride_verb_6

definition.text: to feel very happy and confident

examples.text: They were still riding high after their election victory.

inflections: ( past tense rode / rəʊd $ roʊd /, past participle ridden / ˈrɪdn / )
title: ride_verb_7

definition.text: to take no action about something that is wrong or unpleasant

examples.text: What he had said was wrong, and I knew I shouldn’t just let it ride.

inflections: ( past tense rode / rəʊd $ roʊd /, past participle ridden / ˈrɪdn / )
title: ride_verb_8

definition.text: to ignore someone else’s feelings or ideas because you have the power or authority to do this

examples.text: The planning authorities should not ride roughshod over the wishes of local people.

inflections: ( past tense rode / rəʊd $ roʊd /, past participle ridden / ˈrɪdn / )
title: ride_verb_9

definition.text: to annoy someone by often criticizing them or asking them to do things

examples.text: Why are you riding her so hard?

inflections: ( past tense rode / rəʊd $ roʊd /, past participle ridden / ˈrɪdn / )
title: ride_verb_10

definition.text: if a child rides on someone’s shoulders or back, they are carried in that way

inflections: ( past tense rode / rəʊd $ roʊd /, past participle ridden / ˈrɪdn / )
title: ride_verb_11

definition.text: to move back slightly when someone hits you, so that you are not hit with so much force

examples.text: He managed to ride the punch.

inflections: ( past tense rode / rəʊd $ roʊd /, past participle ridden / ˈrɪdn / )
title: ride_verb_12

definition.text: to be doing something unwise which could result in failure

examples.text: I had a feeling he was riding for a fall, and tried to tell him so.

definition.text: used to tell someone, especially a child, to be quiet

examples.text: ‘Shush!’ said Jerry. ‘Not so loud.’

definition.text: to tell someone to be very quiet, especially by putting your fingers against your lips or by saying ‘ shush ’

examples.text: He started to cry and Francesca shushed him.

definition.text: having a sharp acid taste, like the taste of a lemon or a fruit that is not ready to be eaten

examples.text: Rachel sampled the wine. It was sour.
sour cherries

f2n.heading: Register
f2n.explanation: In everyday English, people usually say milk goes bad or, in British English, goes off, rather than goes sour .

definition.text: milk or other food that is sour is not fresh and has a bad taste

examples.text: turn/go sour(= become sour )

definition.text: unfriendly or looking bad-tempered

examples.text: sour look/face/smile etc
Eliza was tall and thin, with a rather sour face.
a sour-faced old man

definition.text: if a relationship or plan turns or goes sour, it becomes less enjoyable, pleasant, or satisfactory

examples.text: As time went by, their marriage turned sour .
The meeting ended on a sour note, with neither side able to reach agreement.

definition.text: if a relationship or someone’s attitude sours, or if something sours it, it becomes unfriendly or unfavourable

examples.text: An unhappy childhood has soured her view of life.

definition.text: if milk sours, or if something sours it, it begins to have an unpleasant sharp taste
used to say that someone is pretending that they dislike something because they want it but cannot have it – used to show disapproval
strange or frightening in a way that makes you think of ghosts

meaning.translation: عجیب و غریب یا ترسناک به نحوی که آدم رو یاد روح میندازه

examples.text: a spooky old house
spooky stories
The candlelight created a rather spooky atmosphere.

definition.text: not studying or looking at something carefully and only seeing the most noticeable things

examples.text: superficial examination/study etc
Even a superficial inspection revealed serious flaws.
Naturally, such visits can allow only the most superficial understanding of prison life.

definition.text: seeming to have a particular quality, although this is not true or real

examples.text: superficial resemblance/similarity
Despite their superficial similarities, the two novels are, in fact, very different.
Beneath his refined manners and superficial elegance lay something treacherous.
at/on a superficial level
At a superficial level, things seem to have remained the same.

definition.text: affecting only the surface of your skin or the outside part of something, and therefore not serious

examples.text: She escaped with only superficial cuts and bruises.
superficial damage

definition.text: someone who is superficial does not think about things that are serious or important – used to show disapproval

examples.text: All the other girls seemed silly and superficial to Darlene.

definition.text: superficial changes, difficulties etc are not important and do not have a big effect

examples.text: superficial changes in government policies

definition.text: existing in or relating to the top layer of something, especially soil, rock etc
a type of park where you can have fun riding on big machines such as a roller coaster, and where the whole park is based on one subject such as water or space travel
to organize a party and invite people
to step heavily on something, so that you crush it with your feet

examples.text: trample on/over/through etc
There was a small fence to stop people trampling on the flowers.
trample somebody/something underfoot
The children were in danger of being trampled underfoot in the crowd.
trample somebody to death(= kill someone by stepping heavily on them )
Several people were nearly trampled to death in the rush to get out.

definition.text: to behave in a way that shows that you do not care about someone’s rights or feelings

meaning.translation: لگد مال کردن (نادیده گرفتن حقوق یا احساسات کسی)

examples.text: trample on/over somebody/something
Don’t let people trample all over you.
Their interests and rights had been trampled underfoot .

definition.text: a space inside the front door of a public building
the space at each end of a railway carriage that connects it with the next carriage
used when you are telling someone that something is extremely good, bad etc

examples.text: You have no idea how worried I was.

definition.text: a large area that is different from other areas around it in some way

examples.text: San Francisco and Tokyo are both located in earthquake zones.
The government has set up a special economic zone to promote private enterprise.

definition.text: having all your attention on what you are doing, especially playing a sport, and doing it well

examples.text: When I’m in the zone, every shot seems easy.

definition.text: if an area of land is zoned, it is officially kept to be used for a particular purpose

examples.text: be zoned for something
The land is currently zoned for residential use.

definition.text: a large high open space in a tall building
one of the two spaces in the top of your heart that push blood into the ventricle s
